odeComponent.htmlView:
When we think about musical notes, this is what usually comes to mind:

If we count them, we get seven musical notes, seven sounds: do – re – mi – fa – sol – la – si – do. However, in the Western musical system, we actually have twelve notes, not seven.

{"ideviceId":"202512291721116378BV","textInfoDurationInput":"","textInfoDurationTextInput":"Duración","textInfoParticipantsInput":"","textInfoParticipantsTextInput":"Agrupamiento","textTextarea":"

When we think about musical notes, this is what usually comes to mind:

If we count them, we get seven musical notes, seven sounds: do – re – mi – fa – sol – la – si – do. However, in the Western musical system, we actually have twelve notes, not seven.

","textFeedbackInput":"Mostrar retroalimentación","textFeedbackTextarea":""}

odeComponent.htmlView:
Nowadays, Western music uses twelve different sounds to compose music. We will number them from 1 to 12.

Once we reach note 12, the notes repeat again but sounding higher. In the same way, if we go below note 1, the notes sound lower. The smallest distance between two sounds is called a semitone (ST). The distance of two semitones is called a tone (T). None of these twelve notes is more important than the others. However, when we compose a song, we do not usually use all twelve notes. Instead, we make a selection. That selection is called a scale.

odeComponent.htmlView:
A scale is an ordered sequence of musical notes arranged by pitch, following a specific pattern of intervals (distances between notes). One of the most important and most used scales in Western music is the major scale, which has seven notes and follows this pattern of intervals: T – T – ST- T – T – T – ST. 

We will build it starting from note 1, which is called the tonic (I). Each note of the scale is identified using Roman numerals (I – II – III – IV – V – VI – VII).

In the diagram, when we see a circle, we move two notes forward; when we see a diamond we move one note.

As you can see, we only use the sounds: 1 – 3 – 5 – 6 – 8 -10 y 12. The rest of the notes are marked with a darker colour and an X, because they are not part of the scale. In fact, let’s colour them in black and let’s make them smaller and thinner.

When we put these notes together, we obtain a piano keyboard, where the white keys correspond to the notes of the major scale. The piano was built this way because the major scale was the most commonly used scale. These seven notes are the same ones we saw at the beginning.  The intermediate notes (the black keys) are named using accidentals: a sharp (#) raises the note by one semitone, a flat (b) lowers the note by one semitone, the natural (♮) cancels a sharp or flat

We can now name this scale the do (C) major scale:

  • Do: the tonic is do.
  • Mayor: the distances between the notes follow the pattern T – T – ST- T – T – T – ST.

This means that to build any scale, we only need two elements: the tonic and the interval pattern.

Now let’s create the sol (G) major scale. We place the notes starting from the tonic

Then we apply the major scale pattern:

As we can see, in the sol (G) major scale there is one altered note: we do not use fa (F) natural, but fa♯.

odeComponent.htmlView:
Besides the major scale, another very common scale is the minor scale. It also has seven notes and follows this pattern of intervals: T – ST – T – T – ST – T – T. We are going to build it starting from la (A), forming the la (A) minor scale.

In the case of la (A) minor, we also use the white keys of the piano, just like in the do (C) major scale. This is not a coincidence, because these two scales are relative scales.

In the case of la (A) minor, we also use the white keys of the piano, just like in the do (C) major scale. This is not a coincidence, because these two scales are relative scales.

odeNavStructure.pageName: Major scales and their relative minor scales

odeNavStructureProperty.value: Major scales and their relative minor scales
Major scales and their relative minor scales

odePagStructure.blockName: Major scales and their relative minor scales

odeComponent.htmlView:
Every major scale has a relative minor scale.

  • The relative minor of a major scale starts on the sixth note of the major scale.
  • The relative major of a minor scale starts on the third note of the minor scale.

Relative scales always share the same notes. We have already seen that do (C) major has la (A) minor as its relative. If we take the sol (G) major scale, its sixth note is mi (E), so its relative minor is (E) minor. When we build (mi) E minor following the pattern: T – ST – T – T – ST – T – T.

We can see that it has only one altered note: fa♯, just like sol (G) major. We know it is fa♯ and not sol ♭ because the note G natural is already used in the scale.

odeComponent.htmlView: In Western music we use twelve different sounds, but they are not usually all used at the same time. Instead, they are selected to form scales. A scale is an ordered series of notes that follows a specific pattern of tones and semitones. The most important scales are the major and the minor scales, which have seven notes and a different characteristic sound. Each scale starts on a main note called the tonic and creates a tonality, which is the musical “atmosphere” of a piece. In addition, every major scale has a related minor scale that shares the same notes, called relative scales. There are other scales that you already know, such as the pentatonic scale, but for now we will focus on major and minor scales.

In total, there are @@twelve@@ notes, but when composing music we can select some of these notes and form @@scales@@. For example, if we choose only five notes, we obtain a @@pentatonic@@ scale. All scales start on the first note, which is called the @@tonic@@.

@@Major@@ scales have the following distances between notes: @@tone@@ – tone – @@semitone@@ – tone – @@tone@@ – tone – @@semitone@@.

From a major scale, we can obtain its relative minor scale starting from the @@sixth@@ note of the major scale. For example, in the do (C) major scale, its sixth note is @@la@@, so the relative @@minor@@ scale is la (A) @@minor@@. The distances between notes in a minor scale are: @@tone@@ – semitone – @@tone@@ – tone – @@semitone@@ – tone – @@tone@@.

We must not confuse the relative scale with the @@parallel@@ scale. For example, the parallel scale of do (C) major is do (C) @@minor@@.

In this image we can see the do (C) @@minor@@ scale. We know this because the distances between its notes are: tone – @@semitone@@ – @@tone@@ – @@tone@@ – @@semitone@@ – @@tone@@ – @@tone@@.
